content: Involve your kids in the decision making process. Talk to your children about what their household responsibilities should be, especially if they’re preteens or teenagers. Agree upon specific tasks, and make sure everyone is clear about when those tasks should be completed. [1] For example, you and your child might agree that chores should be completed right after school or as soon as they get home. Alternatively, if they’re supposed to load or unload the dishwasher, it might be best for them to complete that task in the evening after dinnertime. If you have multiple children, hold a family meeting to make sure everyone is on the same page about chore assignments. Ask them, “Does anyone think these tasks are divided up unfairly? Would you prefer to rotate chores, so everyone has different tasks each week?” You can also let your kids choose from a set list of chores so they can decide which ones they'd prefer to do. Assign fewer chores when you know your kids are especially busy. When assigning chores, consider how busy you and your child are, and place your emphasis on family time over busywork. Try to lighten their load during a sports season, during midterms or finals, or when their workload otherwise increases. [2] Chores are often intended to instill a sense of responsibility. However, if your teen is in honors classes, plays soccer, and is in student government, it might be best to ease up on them when it comes to their workload at home. If the family’s schedule is generally hectic, consider assigning everyone a 15 or 20 minute daily task to do together, like getting the kitchen and dining rooms in order after dinner. That way, everyone can talk to each other about their days while still keeping the house tidy. Take your children's ages and abilities into account. Assign tasks that your kids are physically and developmentally able to complete, ideally within 15 or 20 minutes. Try to think of chores that are challenging but not impossible for their age and size. [3] For example, having a five year old fold fitted sheets by themselves is probably beyond their abilities. Likewise, expecting a child who is less than four feet tall dust a shelf twice their height without supervision could be a safety hazard. Age appropriate tasks for pre-kindergartners include: putting clothes in a hamper, matching socks into pairs, and putting toys away [4] Good chores for six year olds include separating laundry, organizing mail, and watering plants. [5] Have your seven or eight year old set and clear the dinner table, take out trash, and dust. [6] If they’re ten or over, have them vacuum, mow the lawn, help prepare dinner, and unload the dishwasher. [7] Break up overwhelming tasks into smaller chores. Instead of telling your child to clean an entire room, try to assign specific, smaller tasks. This will help them clearly understand their responsibilities and make their chores more approachable. [8] For example, instead of saying, “Clean the living room,” you could say: “First, dust the shelves, television cabinet, and side tables. Then, after you’ve dusted, vacuum the floor.” Assign chores that appeal to your child’s interests. If you know your child likes plants, have them water potted plants inside or the garden outside. If they love animals, have them brush, feed, and walk the dog, or clean out their hamster’s cage. Have them help you make dinner if they show interest in cooking, and make it fun by giving them their own chef’s hat and apron. [9] Avoid using chores as punishment. The first step to developing an enjoyable chore routine is to associate chores with positivity. If your child misbehaves, consider withholding a privilege, such as a video game or TV show, instead of adding a task to their list of chores. [10] An exception might be if you have multiple children and one of your kids does something to another. For example, if one child steals from another, have them complete a task normally assigned to the one whose item they stole. Get your kids used to doing chores before turning on electronics. Creating a chore routine involves structure and consistency. Do your best not to let your child turn on the television or their video game system without first finishing a household task. [11] For instance, when they get home from school, make sure their coat is hung up, shoes are away, and bed is made before they can watch TV. Do chores together. Completing tasks with younger children will show them how to do their chores properly and in a timely manner. Doing chores with older children will help you keep in touch with them if they have a busy schedule. [12] For example, have your kindergartner sort laundry with you, preteen wash dishes while you dry them, or teenager tend to the garden with you. If a younger child understands how to complete a task, they’ll be less like to dread their chores. Using chores as a bonding experience with an older child can help enrich your relationship with them. While you're all doing chores together, show your kids that chores can be fun. Put on some music or make a game out of doing the chores, like seeing who can finish them first. Schedule a daily family tidy time. Setting aside a specific time for everyone to clean up will help everyone feel part of a larger whole. Incorporate something fun into the routine to motivate everyone to finish their tasks. [13] For example, after dinner, have everyone do a tidying task: have one person pick up odds and ends around the house, have another handle the dishes or dishwasher, and have someone else wipe down the table and counters. Put on music everyone enjoys and make a party out of cleaning time. After cleaning time, do something fun together, like make sundaes, watch a movie, or play a board game. Use plenty of positive reinforcement. If your child completes a task well and in a timely manner, use age-appropriate language to let them know what a great job they did. When they complete a task without being told, let them know how impressed you are. [14] If your younger child puts their dirty clothes in the hamper without being told, tell them, “I am so proud of you! You did such a great job, and you’re really showing me what a big kid you’re becoming!” If your preteen or teen finishes their chore, try saying, “Hey, it makes me happy to see you handling your responsibilities in such a mature way. Thanks for remembering that today’s your day to clean your room.” Make a chore list . Write down your child’s assigned tasks, and include spaces for gold stars or fun stickers. If they complete their chores on time and without being told for a certain number of consecutive days, they get a reward. [15] For instance, if they make their bed in the morning, put their shoes and coat where they belong, and load the dishwasher, they get a gold star for that day. If they get five gold star days in a row, they get a day off from chores, a small toy, a dollar bonus on their allowance, or other appropriate incentive. Hide goodies that your child will find only if they complete a task. Try to find ways to create a scavenger hide using small rewards. Put quarters under lamps, coffee table books, and other places where your child dusts to encourage them to do their job thoroughly. Hide a candy bar, action figure, or other age appropriate treat at the bottom of clean clothes they’re supposed to fold. [16] Try to use the scavenger hunt technique to encourage your child to complete their tasks without cutting any corners. Mix up your hiding places so they don’t just dig around the bottom of the laundry basket without actually folding clothes. Give your child an allowance. Deciding on an allowance amount and whether to offer one at all depends on affordability, their age, and other personal variables. If you do opt to give your child an allowance, make sure they have to earn it instead of getting a set amount automatically. [17] Make sure they know that they might they might lose a percentage of their allowance if they have to be told more than once to do something or are sloppy about completing a task. Be aware that they might decide they’re fine with losing a dollar a week if it means they don’t have to spend a little extra time being thorough. If an allowance system seems to be encouraging laziness instead of industriousness, consider having a conversation with them about it. Try saying, “An allowance is supposed to encourage you to be proud of and enjoy what you’ve earned, not cut corners. We’re going to take a break from the allowance. We’ll talk about bringing it back a month from now if you can do your chores completely and without being told more than once.”

<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores">How to Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Catherine Valadez Lopez</a>

<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>

<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=catherinevaladezlopez#catherinevaladezlopez">Catherine Valadez Lopez</a>. Catherine Valadez Lopes is a Childcare Center Director in New York. She received her MS in Elementary Education from CUNY Brooklyn College in 2010.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">17 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Assigning your kids chores lends them a sense of responsibility and helps you keep the house in order. Getting them to enjoy household chores can help you avoid complaining, procrastination, and incomplete or sloppy work. Allowing your kids to help choose age appropriate tasks is a valuable start. Assigning chores related to their interests, involving the whole family in a fun routine, and developing a system of rewards will help keep household chores enjoyable for everyone.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Choosing_Appropriate_Chores_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Choosing_Appropriate_Chores">Choosing Appropriate Chores</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d6/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-1.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-1.jpg" height="485" id="img_b4310f2005" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b4310f2005')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d6/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-1.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Involve your kids in the decision making process.</b> Talk to your children about what their household responsibilities should be, especially if they’re preteens or teenagers. Agree upon specific tasks, and make sure everyone is clear about when those tasks should be completed.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, you and your child might agree that chores should be completed right after school or as soon as they get home. Alternatively, if they’re supposed to load or unload the dishwasher, it might be best for them to complete that task in the evening after dinnertime.</li>
<li>If you have multiple children, hold a family meeting to make sure everyone is on the same page about chore assignments. Ask them, “Does anyone think these tasks are divided up unfairly? Would you prefer to rotate chores, so everyone has different tasks each week?”</li>
<li>You can also let your kids choose from a set list of chores so they can decide which ones they'd prefer to do.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-2.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_9392081c38" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9392081c38')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-2.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Assign fewer chores when you know your kids are especially busy.</b> When assigning chores, consider how busy you and your child are, and place your emphasis on family time over busywork. Try to lighten their load during a sports season, during midterms or finals, or when their workload otherwise increases.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Chores are often intended to instill a sense of responsibility. However, if your teen is in honors classes, plays soccer, and is in student government, it might be best to ease up on them when it comes to their workload at home.</li>
<li>If the family’s schedule is generally hectic, consider assigning everyone a 15 or 20 minute daily task to do together, like getting the kitchen and dining rooms in order after dinner. That way, everyone can talk to each other about their days while still keeping the house tidy.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-3.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-3.jpg" height="485" id="img_a3d55aea4b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a3d55aea4b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-3.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take your children's ages and abilities into account.</b> <a href="/Decide-on-Age-Appropriate-Chores-for-Your-Child" title="Decide on Age Appropriate Chores for Your Child">Assign tasks</a> that your kids are physically and developmentally able to complete, ideally within 15 or 20 minutes. Try to think of chores that are challenging but not impossible for their age and size.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, having a five year old fold fitted sheets by themselves is probably beyond their abilities. Likewise, expecting a child who is less than four feet tall dust a shelf twice their height without supervision could be a safety hazard.</li>
<li>Age appropriate tasks for pre-kindergartners include: putting clothes in a hamper, matching socks into pairs, and putting toys away<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Good chores for six year olds include separating laundry, organizing mail, and watering plants.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Have your seven or eight year old set and clear the dinner table, take out trash, and dust.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If they’re ten or over, have them vacuum, mow the lawn, help prepare dinner, and unload the dishwasher.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-4.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-4.jpg" height="485" id="img_d86568f575" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d86568f575')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-4.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Break up overwhelming tasks into smaller chores.</b> Instead of telling your child to clean an entire room, try to assign specific, smaller tasks. This will help them clearly understand their responsibilities and make their chores more approachable.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, instead of saying, “Clean the living room,” you could say: “First, dust the shelves, television cabinet, and side tables. Then, after you’ve dusted, vacuum the floor.”</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-5.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-5.jpg" height="485" id="img_ab43372555" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ab43372555')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-5.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Assign chores that appeal to your child’s interests.</b> If you know your child likes plants, have them water potted plants inside or the garden outside. If they love animals, have them brush, feed, and walk the dog, or clean out their hamster’s cage. Have them help you make dinner if they show interest in cooking, and make it fun by giving them their own chef’s hat and apron.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Creating_Fun_Routines_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Creating_Fun_Routines">Creating Fun Routines</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-6.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-6.jpg" height="485" id="img_fc7400da4d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fc7400da4d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-6.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid using chores as punishment.</b> The first step to developing an enjoyable chore routine is to associate chores with positivity. If your child misbehaves, consider withholding a privilege, such as a video game or TV show, instead of adding a task to their list of chores.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>An exception might be if you have multiple children and one of your kids does something to another. For example, if one child steals from another, have them complete a task normally assigned to the one whose item they stole.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-7.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-7.jpg" height="485" id="img_6417bb1317" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_6417bb1317')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-7.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get your kids used to doing chores before turning on electronics.</b> Creating a chore routine involves structure and consistency. Do your best not to let your child turn on the television or their video game system without first finishing a household task.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For instance, when they get home from school, make sure their coat is hung up, shoes are away, and bed is made before they can watch TV.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-8.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-8.jpg" height="485" id="img_d4f0d066a2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d4f0d066a2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-8.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do chores together.</b> Completing tasks with younger children will show them how to do their chores properly and in a timely manner. Doing chores with older children will help you keep in touch with them if they have a busy schedule.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, have your kindergartner sort laundry with you, preteen wash dishes while you dry them, or teenager tend to the garden with you.</li>
<li>If a younger child understands how to complete a task, they’ll be less like to dread their chores. Using chores as a bonding experience with an older child can help enrich your relationship with them.</li>
<li>While you're all doing chores together, show your kids that chores can be fun. Put on some music or make a game out of doing the chores, like seeing who can finish them first.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-9.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-9.jpg" height="485" id="img_c9199b7020" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c9199b7020')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-9.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Schedule a daily family tidy time.</b> Setting aside a specific time for everyone to clean up will help everyone feel part of a larger whole. Incorporate something fun into the routine to motivate everyone to finish their tasks.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, after dinner, have everyone do a tidying task: have one person pick up odds and ends around the house, have another handle the dishes or dishwasher, and have someone else wipe down the table and counters.</li>
<li>Put on music everyone enjoys and make a party out of cleaning time.</li>
<li>After cleaning time, do something fun together, like make sundaes, watch a movie, or play a board game.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Creating_a_Rewards_System_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Creating_a_Rewards_System">Creating a Rewards System</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-10.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-10.jpg" height="485" id="img_8728083fec" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8728083fec')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-10.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use plenty of positive reinforcement.</b> If your child completes a task well and in a timely manner, use age-appropriate language to let them know what a great job they did. When they complete a task without being told, let them know how impressed you are.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If your younger child puts their dirty clothes in the hamper without being told, tell them, “I am so proud of you! You did such a great job, and you’re really showing me what a big kid you’re becoming!”</li>
<li>If your preteen or teen finishes their chore, try saying, “Hey, it makes me happy to see you handling your responsibilities in such a mature way. Thanks for remembering that today’s your day to clean your room.”</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-11.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-11.jpg" height="485" id="img_9f8d173cf8" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9f8d173cf8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-11.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make a <a href="/Make-a-Chore-Chart" title="Make a Chore Chart">chore list</a>.</b> Write down your child’s assigned tasks, and include spaces for gold stars or fun stickers. If they complete their chores on time and without being told for a certain number of consecutive days, they get a reward.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For instance, if they make their bed in the morning, put their shoes and coat where they belong, and load the dishwasher, they get a gold star for that day.</li>
<li>If they get five gold star days in a row, they get a day off from chores, a small toy, a dollar bonus on their allowance, or other appropriate incentive.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-12.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-12.jpg" height="485" id="img_0e08ac9d99" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0e08ac9d99')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-12.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Hide goodies that your child will find only if they complete a task.</b> Try to find ways to create a scavenger hide using small rewards. Put quarters under lamps, coffee table books, and other places where your child dusts to encourage them to do their job thoroughly. Hide a candy bar, action figure, or other age appropriate treat at the bottom of clean clothes they’re supposed to fold.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Try to use the scavenger hunt technique to encourage your child to complete their tasks without cutting any corners.</li>
<li>Mix up your hiding places so they don’t just dig around the bottom of the laundry basket without actually folding clothes.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8255293" href="#/Image:Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-13.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-13.jpg" height="485" id="img_86ef9c753e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_86ef9c753e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-13.jpg/aid8255293-v4-728px-Help-Your-Kids-Enjoy-Chores-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Give your child an allowance.</b> Deciding on an allowance amount and whether to offer one at all depends on affordability, their age, and other personal variables. If you do opt to give your child an allowance, make sure they have to earn it instead of getting a set amount automatically.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Make sure they know that they might they might lose a percentage of their allowance if they have to be told more than once to do something or are sloppy about completing a task.</li>
<li>Be aware that they might decide they’re fine with losing a dollar a week if it means they don’t have to spend a little extra time being thorough. If an allowance system seems to be encouraging laziness instead of industriousness, consider having a conversation with them about it.</li>
<li>Try saying, “An allowance is supposed to encourage you to be proud of and enjoy what you’ve earned, not cut corners. We’re going to take a break from the allowance. We’ll talk about bringing it back a month from now if you can do your chores completely and without being told more than once.”</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",

        },
        "sameAs": [

    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Choosing Appropriate Chores",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Involve your kids in the decision making process. Talk to your children about what their household responsibilities should be, especially if they\u2019re preteens or teenagers. Agree upon specific tasks, and make sure everyone is clear about when those tasks should be completed.[1]\nFor example, you and your child might agree that chores should be completed right after school or as soon as they get home. Alternatively, if they\u2019re supposed to load or unload the dishwasher, it might be best for them to complete that task in the evening after dinnertime.\nIf you have multiple children, hold a family meeting to make sure everyone is on the same page about chore assignments. Ask them, \u201cDoes anyone think these tasks are divided up unfairly? Would you prefer to rotate chores, so everyone has different tasks each week?\u201d\nYou can also let your kids choose from a set list of chores so they can decide which ones they'd prefer to do."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Assign fewer chores when you know your kids are especially busy. When assigning chores, consider how busy you and your child are, and place your emphasis on family time over busywork. Try to lighten their load during a sports season, during midterms or finals, or when their workload otherwise increases.[2]\nChores are often intended to instill a sense of responsibility. However, if your teen is in honors classes, plays soccer, and is in student government, it might be best to ease up on them when it comes to their workload at home.\nIf the family\u2019s schedule is generally hectic, consider assigning everyone a 15 or 20 minute daily task to do together, like getting the kitchen and dining rooms in order after dinner. That way, everyone can talk to each other about their days while still keeping the house tidy."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Take your children's ages and abilities into account. Assign tasks that your kids are physically and developmentally able to complete, ideally within 15 or 20 minutes. Try to think of chores that are challenging but not impossible for their age and size.[3]\nFor example, having a five year old fold fitted sheets by themselves is probably beyond their abilities. Likewise, expecting a child who is less than four feet tall dust a shelf twice their height without supervision could be a safety hazard.\nAge appropriate tasks for pre-kindergartners include: putting clothes in a hamper, matching socks into pairs, and putting toys away[4]\nGood chores for six year olds include separating laundry, organizing mail, and watering plants.[5]\nHave your seven or eight year old set and clear the dinner table, take out trash, and dust.[6]\nIf they\u2019re ten or over, have them vacuum, mow the lawn, help prepare dinner, and unload the dishwasher.[7]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Break up overwhelming tasks into smaller chores. Instead of telling your child to clean an entire room, try to assign specific, smaller tasks. This will help them clearly understand their responsibilities and make their chores more approachable.[8]\nFor example, instead of saying, \u201cClean the living room,\u201d you could say: \u201cFirst, dust the shelves, television cabinet, and side tables. Then, after you\u2019ve dusted, vacuum the floor.\u201d"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Assign chores that appeal to your child\u2019s interests. If you know your child likes plants, have them water potted plants inside or the garden outside. If they love animals, have them brush, feed, and walk the dog, or clean out their hamster\u2019s cage. Have them help you make dinner if they show interest in cooking, and make it fun by giving them their own chef\u2019s hat and apron.[9]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Creating Fun Routines",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid using chores as punishment. The first step to developing an enjoyable chore routine is to associate chores with positivity. If your child misbehaves, consider withholding a privilege, such as a video game or TV show, instead of adding a task to their list of chores.[10]\nAn exception might be if you have multiple children and one of your kids does something to another. For example, if one child steals from another, have them complete a task normally assigned to the one whose item they stole."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Get your kids used to doing chores before turning on electronics. Creating a chore routine involves structure and consistency. Do your best not to let your child turn on the television or their video game system without first finishing a household task.[11]\nFor instance, when they get home from school, make sure their coat is hung up, shoes are away, and bed is made before they can watch TV."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Do chores together. Completing tasks with younger children will show them how to do their chores properly and in a timely manner. Doing chores with older children will help you keep in touch with them if they have a busy schedule.[12]\nFor example, have your kindergartner sort laundry with you, preteen wash dishes while you dry them, or teenager tend to the garden with you.\nIf a younger child understands how to complete a task, they\u2019ll be less like to dread their chores. Using chores as a bonding experience with an older child can help enrich your relationship with them.\nWhile you're all doing chores together, show your kids that chores can be fun. Put on some music or make a game out of doing the chores, like seeing who can finish them first."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Schedule a daily family tidy time. Setting aside a specific time for everyone to clean up will help everyone feel part of a larger whole. Incorporate something fun into the routine to motivate everyone to finish their tasks.[13]\nFor example, after dinner, have everyone do a tidying task: have one person pick up odds and ends around the house, have another handle the dishes or dishwasher, and have someone else wipe down the table and counters.\nPut on music everyone enjoys and make a party out of cleaning time.\nAfter cleaning time, do something fun together, like make sundaes, watch a movie, or play a board game."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Creating a Rewards System",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use plenty of positive reinforcement. If your child completes a task well and in a timely manner, use age-appropriate language to let them know what a great job they did. When they complete a task without being told, let them know how impressed you are.[14]\nIf your younger child puts their dirty clothes in the hamper without being told, tell them, \u201cI am so proud of you! You did such a great job, and you\u2019re really showing me what a big kid you\u2019re becoming!\u201d\nIf your preteen or teen finishes their chore, try saying, \u201cHey, it makes me happy to see you handling your responsibilities in such a mature way. Thanks for remembering that today\u2019s your day to clean your room.\u201d"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Make a chore list. Write down your child\u2019s assigned tasks, and include spaces for gold stars or fun stickers. If they complete their chores on time and without being told for a certain number of consecutive days, they get a reward.[15]\nFor instance, if they make their bed in the morning, put their shoes and coat where they belong, and load the dishwasher, they get a gold star for that day.\nIf they get five gold star days in a row, they get a day off from chores, a small toy, a dollar bonus on their allowance, or other appropriate incentive."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Hide goodies that your child will find only if they complete a task. Try to find ways to create a scavenger hide using small rewards. Put quarters under lamps, coffee table books, and other places where your child dusts to encourage them to do their job thoroughly. Hide a candy bar, action figure, or other age appropriate treat at the bottom of clean clothes they\u2019re supposed to fold.[16]\nTry to use the scavenger hunt technique to encourage your child to complete their tasks without cutting any corners.\nMix up your hiding places so they don\u2019t just dig around the bottom of the laundry basket without actually folding clothes."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Give your child an allowance. Deciding on an allowance amount and whether to offer one at all depends on affordability, their age, and other personal variables. If you do opt to give your child an allowance, make sure they have to earn it instead of getting a set amount automatically.[17]\nMake sure they know that they might they might lose a percentage of their allowance if they have to be told more than once to do something or are sloppy about completing a task.\nBe aware that they might decide they\u2019re fine with losing a dollar a week if it means they don\u2019t have to spend a little extra time being thorough. If an allowance system seems to be encouraging laziness instead of industriousness, consider having a conversation with them about it.\nTry saying, \u201cAn allowance is supposed to encourage you to be proud of and enjoy what you\u2019ve earned, not cut corners. We\u2019re going to take a break from the allowance. We\u2019ll talk about bringing it back a month from now if you can do your chores completely and without being told more than once.\u201d"
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "description": "How to Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores. Assigning your kids chores lends them a sense of responsibility and helps you keep the house in order. Getting them to enjoy household chores can help you avoid complaining, procrastination, and..."
}</script>

title: How to Help Your Kids Enjoy Chores
content_html:
Involve your kids in the decision making process. Talk to your children about what their household responsibilities should be, especially if they’re preteens or teenagers. Agree upon specific tasks, and make sure everyone is clear about when those tasks should be completed.[1]
  • For example, you and your child might agree that chores should be completed right after school or as soon as they get home. Alternatively, if they’re supposed to load or unload the dishwasher, it might be best for them to complete that task in the evening after dinnertime.
  • If you have multiple children, hold a family meeting to make sure everyone is on the same page about chore assignments. Ask them, “Does anyone think these tasks are divided up unfairly? Would you prefer to rotate chores, so everyone has different tasks each week?”
  • You can also let your kids choose from a set list of chores so they can decide which ones they'd prefer to do.
Assign fewer chores when you know your kids are especially busy. When assigning chores, consider how busy you and your child are, and place your emphasis on family time over busywork. Try to lighten their load during a sports season, during midterms or finals, or when their workload otherwise increases.[2]
  • Chores are often intended to instill a sense of responsibility. However, if your teen is in honors classes, plays soccer, and is in student government, it might be best to ease up on them when it comes to their workload at home.
  • If the family’s schedule is generally hectic, consider assigning everyone a 15 or 20 minute daily task to do together, like getting the kitchen and dining rooms in order after dinner. That way, everyone can talk to each other about their days while still keeping the house tidy.
Take your children's ages and abilities into account. Assign tasks that your kids are physically and developmentally able to complete, ideally within 15 or 20 minutes. Try to think of chores that are challenging but not impossible for their age and size.[3]
  • For example, having a five year old fold fitted sheets by themselves is probably beyond their abilities. Likewise, expecting a child who is less than four feet tall dust a shelf twice their height without supervision could be a safety hazard.
  • Age appropriate tasks for pre-kindergartners include: putting clothes in a hamper, matching socks into pairs, and putting toys away[4]
  • Good chores for six year olds include separating laundry, organizing mail, and watering plants.[5]
  • Have your seven or eight year old set and clear the dinner table, take out trash, and dust.[6]
  • If they’re ten or over, have them vacuum, mow the lawn, help prepare dinner, and unload the dishwasher.[7]
Break up overwhelming tasks into smaller chores. Instead of telling your child to clean an entire room, try to assign specific, smaller tasks. This will help them clearly understand their responsibilities and make their chores more approachable.[8]
  • For example, instead of saying, “Clean the living room,” you could say: “First, dust the shelves, television cabinet, and side tables. Then, after you’ve dusted, vacuum the floor.”
Assign chores that appeal to your child’s interests. If you know your child likes plants, have them water potted plants inside or the garden outside. If they love animals, have them brush, feed, and walk the dog, or clean out their hamster’s cage. Have them help you make dinner if they show interest in cooking, and make it fun by giving them their own chef’s hat and apron.[9]
Avoid using chores as punishment. The first step to developing an enjoyable chore routine is to associate chores with positivity. If your child misbehaves, consider withholding a privilege, such as a video game or TV show, instead of adding a task to their list of chores.[10]
  • An exception might be if you have multiple children and one of your kids does something to another. For example, if one child steals from another, have them complete a task normally assigned to the one whose item they stole.
Get your kids used to doing chores before turning on electronics. Creating a chore routine involves structure and consistency. Do your best not to let your child turn on the television or their video game system without first finishing a household task.[11]
  • For instance, when they get home from school, make sure their coat is hung up, shoes are away, and bed is made before they can watch TV.
Do chores together. Completing tasks with younger children will show them how to do their chores properly and in a timely manner. Doing chores with older children will help you keep in touch with them if they have a busy schedule.[12]
  • For example, have your kindergartner sort laundry with you, preteen wash dishes while you dry them, or teenager tend to the garden with you.
  • If a younger child understands how to complete a task, they’ll be less like to dread their chores. Using chores as a bonding experience with an older child can help enrich your relationship with them.
  • While you're all doing chores together, show your kids that chores can be fun. Put on some music or make a game out of doing the chores, like seeing who can finish them first.
Schedule a daily family tidy time. Setting aside a specific time for everyone to clean up will help everyone feel part of a larger whole. Incorporate something fun into the routine to motivate everyone to finish their tasks.[13]
  • For example, after dinner, have everyone do a tidying task: have one person pick up odds and ends around the house, have another handle the dishes or dishwasher, and have someone else wipe down the table and counters.
  • Put on music everyone enjoys and make a party out of cleaning time.
  • After cleaning time, do something fun together, like make sundaes, watch a movie, or play a board game.
Use plenty of positive reinforcement. If your child completes a task well and in a timely manner, use age-appropriate language to let them know what a great job they did. When they complete a task without being told, let them know how impressed you are.[14]
  • If your younger child puts their dirty clothes in the hamper without being told, tell them, “I am so proud of you! You did such a great job, and you’re really showing me what a big kid you’re becoming!”
  • If your preteen or teen finishes their chore, try saying, “Hey, it makes me happy to see you handling your responsibilities in such a mature way. Thanks for remembering that today’s your day to clean your room.”
Make a chore list. Write down your child’s assigned tasks, and include spaces for gold stars or fun stickers. If they complete their chores on time and without being told for a certain number of consecutive days, they get a reward.[15]
  • For instance, if they make their bed in the morning, put their shoes and coat where they belong, and load the dishwasher, they get a gold star for that day.
  • If they get five gold star days in a row, they get a day off from chores, a small toy, a dollar bonus on their allowance, or other appropriate incentive.
Hide goodies that your child will find only if they complete a task. Try to find ways to create a scavenger hide using small rewards. Put quarters under lamps, coffee table books, and other places where your child dusts to encourage them to do their job thoroughly. Hide a candy bar, action figure, or other age appropriate treat at the bottom of clean clothes they’re supposed to fold.[16]
  • Try to use the scavenger hunt technique to encourage your child to complete their tasks without cutting any corners.
  • Mix up your hiding places so they don’t just dig around the bottom of the laundry basket without actually folding clothes.
Give your child an allowance. Deciding on an allowance amount and whether to offer one at all depends on affordability, their age, and other personal variables. If you do opt to give your child an allowance, make sure they have to earn it instead of getting a set amount automatically.[17]
  • Make sure they know that they might they might lose a percentage of their allowance if they have to be told more than once to do something or are sloppy about completing a task.
  • Be aware that they might decide they’re fine with losing a dollar a week if it means they don’t have to spend a little extra time being thorough. If an allowance system seems to be encouraging laziness instead of industriousness, consider having a conversation with them about it.
  • Try saying, “An allowance is supposed to encourage you to be proud of and enjoy what you’ve earned, not cut corners. We’re going to take a break from the allowance. We’ll talk about bringing it back a month from now if you can do your chores completely and without being told more than once.”
